oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ronnie McDowell Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Ronnie McDowell (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ronnie McDowell; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ronnie McDowell radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (00:09) Collie softly describes the structure of the radio spots -- (00:20) McDowell says "Hey, couldn't be any better" -- (00:26) McDowell says "Goes together like Gene Autry, Champion, and Back in the Saddle Again" -- (00:33) McDowell radio spot introducing the break for the Music City Album Review -- (00:42) McDowell radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (00:54) McDowell radio spot declaring that they are having fun for the Music City Album Review -- (01:05) McDowell radio spot declaring the audience does not put off listening to the Music City Album Review -- (01:17) McDowell radio spot declaring "You can't lose if you listen to Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review" -- (01:28) McDowell radio spot addressing that he is hosting the Music City Album Review with Collie -- (01:38) McDowell thirty-minute break radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (01:48) McDowell hour break radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (01:58) McDowell return-from-break radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (02:08) McDowell ninety-minute break radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (02:16) McDowell says his goodbyes for the Music City Album Review radio spot -- (02:28) McDowell discusses how "The King is Gone" was put on his greatest hits because of its overall popularity -- (03:07) "It's Only Make Believe" is told by McDowell to be a song he had to entice Conway Twitty to sing on -- (04:18) McDowell recalls being in Charlotte and listening to his son, Tyler D. McDowell, be born over the phone -- (04:53) Collie and McDowell discuss McDowell's children's weight and age [incomplete] -- (05:18) "I Love You, I Love You, I Love You" is said to be a good album for McDowell, and McDowell says his producer did not McDowell to sing like McDowell -- (06:39) "Sheet Music" is recalled by McDowell to be a song by Joe Metter; McDowell says this is his first 'gut-feeling' song -- (07:58) "I'm Still Missing You" is told by McDowell to be his attempt to create a song similar to Elvis Presley's style; McDowell recalls calling Gordon Stoker for assistance -- (08:49) Collie has McDowell recall his feelings when The King is Gone was released; McDowell was broke at the time The King is Gone was released -- (11:20) McDowell recalls working in Mitchellville, Tennessee on a snowy night when he wrote "All Tied Up" -- (12:37) McDowell reflects on the nature of working in music -- (13:17) McDowell tells about how Troy Seals convinced him to record "Since I Don't Have You;" McDowell had difficulty changing the track into country -- (14:20) McDowell associates "She's a Little Past Forty" to the Calgary Stampede and McDowell's trust in radio -- (15:19) McDowell discusses the demographic that relates to "She's a Little Past Forty" -- (15:38) Collie has McDowell discuss how McDowell is releasing a greatest hits album of Curb Records recordings because he had already done one for CBS Records -- (17:02) Collie and McDowell converse about the association people make for McDowell and Presley; Collie points out how he did not have pictures with Hank Williams, despite the fact Collie had helped Williams -- (18:16) McDowell speaks about the pride he has to be associated with Presley, and Collie and McDowell express how they believe people are jealous of McDowell's ability -- (19:23) McDowell talks about writing "American Music" with Seals, and McDowell praises Seals while talking about his unique music video associated with "American Music" -- (20:31) McDowell speaks on the difficulty on hand-painting each frame for a two-minute music video -- (21:36) McDowell tells how he took a line, from another song, to create "Watching the Girls Go By," and McDowell says it's a follow-up to "Wandering Eyes" -- (23:04) Collie and McDowell reflect on how McDowell will be sent scripts and McDowell will go in the studio with little guidance -- (24:01) McDowell recalls all the Presley songs he recorded, and McDowell and Collie reflect on how people lost interest in Presley -- (24:50) McDowell says, "It's either that Biff, or it doesn't have enough dirt to it. It's too clean"
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: McDowell, Ronnie; Collie, Biff;
